articles.title: A charity is giving people money to stop homelessness - and it says it's working
articles.summary: Providing money gives people at risk of losing their home the "dignity of choice", says the charity's boss.
articles.content:
A charity is giving people money to stop homelessness - and it says it's working

5 hours ago Share Save Michael Buchanan Social affairs correspondent Share Save

BBC News Laura Burns was given £600 by a charity when she needed to move flats

When Laura Burns was asked to leave her flat as her landlord was selling up, she discovered she didn't have enough money to move. Energy debts and removal costs meant she needed hundreds of pounds to get a new flat. Feeling trapped and facing eviction, the mother-of-one turned to a charity and asked for £600. The money came through almost instantly. "I was like, 'oh my goodness', this is a weight off my mind," says the 32-year-old from Didcot, in Oxfordshire. "There are no words to describe leaving that stress behind."

Greater Change, the charity that helped Laura, believes giving money to people who are homeless or those at risk of losing their properties with few strings attached can help tackle homelessness. So far this year, it says the charity has paid out £699,000 to 403 people. The initiative is small in scale – the homeless charity Shelter estimated there were more than 350,000 homeless people in England at the end of last year. But Greater Change says the scheme has the potential to save money in the long-run. "We're giving people dignity of choice," says the charity's chief executive, Jonathan Tan. "Very often, in a homelessness pathway, it feels like it's things being done to you and so we're giving people the ability to make choices about their lives."

BBC News Greater Change CEO Jonathan Tan says the charity gives people the "dignity of choice"

The money is paid out through a support worker and the charity says it will listen to all requests for help. It says people typically spend the money on rent deposits, bills or tackling debts. Greater Change, which was formed by two university friends in 2018, is funded from donations, philanthropists, grant-making bodies and councils. It says its approach saves taxpayers tens of thousands of pounds per client by preventing people from becoming homeless and therefore needing support from their local authority. "We're happy to fund anything under the sun as long as it aligns with the individual's ambitions and helps them to take that next big step out of homelessness," says Mr Tan. The charity says 86% of people it has supported moved into stable housing, with almost half finding a job. But one concern is homeless people could spend the money on feeding addictions. Asked how the charity ensures the money it gives out isn't spent on drugs and alcohol, Mr Tan says: "The first and most important thing to say is the international evidence is that people tend to make pretty good choices." He says almost half of those supported were able to get a job. One of the studies he points to is the New Leaf project, in Vancouver, Canada. It gave 50 people who were homeless around £4,000 (CAD$7,500) each directly rather than via a support worker. It also monitored another 65 homeless people who they didn't help. A follow-up study showed that after a year, those who had received the money spent fewer days without a home. There was also no evidence that they had increased spending on things like drugs, alcohol and tobacco. A smaller scale project in the UK has shown similar results. The Personal Grants project, which involved 81 people, led by the London-based St Martin-in-the-Fields charity working alongside organisations in Glasgow, Oxford and Swansea, paid money directly into the bank accounts of homeless people. The Personal Grants project has not had "a single adverse incident among any participants", according to the Centre for Homelessness Impact, which also worked on the scheme. They say people spent the money on furniture, books, clothes or simply saved it. "None spent the money on drugs, alcohol, or gambling," say the Centre. They are now recruiting 250 people in Belfast and London to test the concept on a larger scale, with the project overseen by researchers from Kings College, London.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a charity providing direct financial support to people at risk of homelessness, enabling them dignity and choice, with evidence of positive outcomes such as stable housing and employment. The initiative addresses a significant social issue with measurable benefits and potential for broader impact, supported by research and expanding projects.
articles.personality_title: Charity helps prevent homelessness by giving people money directly
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Many people face homelessness because they don’t have enough money to pay rent, deposits, or bills. Traditional help can be slow or come with many rules, which can make it hard for people to get back on their feet.

**What happened** – A charity called Greater Change has been giving money directly to people at risk of losing their homes. For example, Laura Burns from Oxfordshire received £600 quickly when she needed help to move flats. The charity has given out nearly £700,000 to 403 people this year, helping them pay rent deposits, bills, or debts.

**Impact** – This approach gives people the freedom to decide how best to use the money, which helps them feel respected and supported. So far, 86% of people helped have found stable housing, and nearly half have found jobs. Studies from Canada and the UK show that giving money directly does not lead to more spending on drugs or alcohol. Instead, people use it for important needs like furniture, clothes, or saving.

**What’s next step** – The charity and researchers are expanding this approach to more people in cities like Belfast and London. They hope to learn more about how direct financial help can stop homelessness and improve lives on a larger scale.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Giving money directly to people at risk of homelessness helps them make their own choices and leads to more stable housing and jobs.

articles.title: Thailand Allows Myanmar Refugees in Camps to Work Legally
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Refugees at the Mae La refugee camp in Mae Sot, Thailand, March 5, 2025.
                    © 2025 Valeria Mongelli/Anadolu via Getty Images
          
    


  
On August 26, Thailand’s cabinet approved measures allowing Myanmar refugees living in camps along the border to work legally. For many, it will be the first formal employment of their lives. About 108,000 refugees live in the nine camps that have sheltered people fleeing Myanmar military abuses since the 1980s. Nearly half were born there. The new work permits will only be available to about 80,000 refugees registered with the Thai government, an estimated 42,000 of whom are working age. Refugees will be required to apply for permission to leave the camps and for work permits valid up to one year. For decades, the Thai government barred camp refugees from working legally, moving freely, or accessing public services, leaving them largely dependent on foreign aid. Desperation in the camps soared this year following drastic US government aid cuts to core food and healthcare services, with monthly rations slashed first to US$2.30, then to zero.In July, I spoke with eight refugees who described feeling hopeless and forgotten after decades restricted to the camps. All were eager to work outside them if allowed. “If we could have some sort of status to grant us protection, to live and work freely and make money, then we wouldn’t be a burden on Thailand or the international community,” one refugee said. The cabinet decision comes at a critical juncture not only for the refugees, but also for the Thai labor force, which is facing shortages due to an aging population and the exodus of at least 100,000 Cambodian migrant workers following recent border clashes.Thai authorities should ensure the permit application process is transparent, accessible, and prompt, with protections in place to avoid exploitation or extortion by brokers. If properly implemented, the work policy will build refugees’ self-reliance and independence, boost local economies, and be a rights-respecting, prosperous model for refugee populations elsewhere in Thailand and in the region. “As young people, we want to make a living, we want to use our knowledge and skills,” another refugee told me. “If there’s any chance for us to leave the camp to work, to get a job and provide for our families, I would take it.”
articles.content:
Click to expand Image Refugees at the Mae La refugee camp in Mae Sot, Thailand, March 5, 2025. © 2025 Valeria Mongelli/Anadolu via Getty Images

On August 26, Thailand’s cabinet approved measures allowing Myanmar refugees living in camps along the border to work legally. For many, it will be the first formal employment of their lives.

About 108,000 refugees live in the nine camps that have sheltered people fleeing Myanmar military abuses since the 1980s. Nearly half were born there.

The new work permits will only be available to about 80,000 refugees registered with the Thai government, an estimated 42,000 of whom are working age. Refugees will be required to apply for permission to leave the camps and for work permits valid up to one year.

For decades, the Thai government barred camp refugees from working legally, moving freely, or accessing public services, leaving them largely dependent on foreign aid. Desperation in the camps soared this year following drastic US government aid cuts to core food and healthcare services, with monthly rations slashed first to US$2.30, then to zero.

In July, I spoke with eight refugees who described feeling hopeless and forgotten after decades restricted to the camps. All were eager to work outside them if allowed. “If we could have some sort of status to grant us protection, to live and work freely and make money, then we wouldn’t be a burden on Thailand or the international community,” one refugee said.

The cabinet decision comes at a critical juncture not only for the refugees, but also for the Thai labor force, which is facing shortages due to an aging population and the exodus of at least 100,000 Cambodian migrant workers following recent border clashes.

Thai authorities should ensure the permit application process is transparent, accessible, and prompt, with protections in place to avoid exploitation or extortion by brokers. If properly implemented, the work policy will build refugees’ self-reliance and independence, boost local economies, and be a rights-respecting, prosperous model for refugee populations elsewhere in Thailand and in the region.

“As young people, we want to make a living, we want to use our knowledge and skills,” another refugee told me. “If there’s any chance for us to leave the camp to work, to get a job and provide for our families, I would take it.”
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant policy change by the Thai government allowing Myanmar refugees in camps to work legally for the first time, which has broad positive implications for tens of thousands of refugees. This change promotes human rights by granting refugees the ability to live with dignity, gain self-reliance, and contribute economically, addressing a long-standing humanitarian issue with substantial social impact.
articles.personality_title: Thailand allows Myanmar refugees to work legally for the first time
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – For decades, Myanmar refugees living in camps along the Thailand border could not work legally or move freely. These camps have sheltered people fleeing violence in Myanmar since the 1980s. Nearly half of the 108,000 refugees living in these camps were born there and have faced limited opportunities.

**What happened** – On August 26, 2025, Thailand’s cabinet approved a new rule letting registered Myanmar refugees apply for work permits. About 80,000 refugees registered with the government are eligible, with around 42,000 of them being adults able to work. Refugees will need permission to leave the camps and can get permits valid for one year.

**Impact** – This is the first time many refugees can have formal jobs, which helps them support themselves and their families. Until now, refugees depended mostly on foreign aid, which has recently been cut, causing food shortages. The new policy also helps Thailand by easing labor shortages caused by an aging population and fewer migrant workers from Cambodia.

**What's next step** – Thai authorities must make sure the permit process is clear, fair, and fast, protecting refugees from being taken advantage of. If done well, this change could improve refugees’ independence and boost local economies. It may also serve as a good example for other countries in the region.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Thailand’s new work permits give Myanmar refugees a chance to live more independently and contribute to their communities for the first time in decades.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Thaïlande autorise les réfugiés birmans à travailler légalement pour la première fois
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Depuis des décennies, les réfugiés birmans vivant dans des camps à la frontière thaïlandaise ne pouvaient pas travailler légalement ni se déplacer librement. Ces camps abritent des personnes fuyant la violence au Myanmar depuis les années 1980. Près de la moitié des 108 000 réfugiés y sont nés et ont peu d’opportunités.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 26 août 2025, le cabinet thaïlandais a approuvé une nouvelle règle permettant aux réfugiés birmans enregistrés de demander des permis de travail. Environ 80 000 réfugiés enregistrés sont éligibles, dont environ 42 000 adultes en âge de travailler. Les réfugiés devront obtenir une autorisation pour quitter les camps, avec des permis valables un an.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois que beaucoup de réfugiés peuvent avoir un emploi officiel, ce qui les aide à subvenir à leurs besoins et à ceux de leur famille. Jusqu’à présent, ils dépendaient surtout de l’aide étrangère, récemment réduite, causant des pénuries alimentaires. Cette politique aide aussi la Thaïlande face à une pénurie de main-d’œuvre due au vieillissement de la population et à la baisse des travailleurs migrants cambodgiens.

**Prochaine étape** – Les autorités thaïlandaises doivent s’assurer que la procédure de demande soit claire, juste et rapide, protégeant les réfugiés contre toute exploitation. Bien mise en œuvre, cette mesure pourrait renforcer l’indépendance des réfugiés et dynamiser l’économie locale, tout en servant d’exemple à d’autres pays de la région.

**En une phrase** – Les nouveaux permis de travail en Thaïlande offrent aux réfugiés birmans la possibilité de vivre plus indépendamment et de contribuer à leur communauté pour la première fois depuis des décennies.
articles.personality_title_es: Tailandia permite por primera vez que refugiados birmanos trabajen legalmente
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante décadas, los refugiados birmanos que viven en campamentos en la frontera con Tailandia no pudieron trabajar legalmente ni moverse libremente. Estos campamentos han acogido a personas que huyen de la violencia en Myanmar desde los años 80. Casi la mitad de los 108,000 refugiados nacieron allí y tienen pocas oportunidades.

**Qué pasó** – El 26 de agosto de 2025, el gabinete tailandés aprobó una norma que permite a los refugiados birmanos registrados solicitar permisos de trabajo. Aproximadamente 80,000 refugiados registrados son elegibles, con unos 42,000 adultos en edad de trabajar. Los refugiados deberán pedir permiso para salir de los campamentos y los permisos serán válidos por un año.

**Impacto** – Por primera vez, muchos refugiados podrán tener empleos formales, lo que les ayudará a mantenerse y apoyar a sus familias. Hasta ahora, dependían principalmente de la ayuda extranjera, que se ha reducido, causando escasez de alimentos. Esta política también ayuda a Tailandia a enfrentar la falta de trabajadores debido al envejecimiento de su población y a la salida de trabajadores migrantes camboyanos.

**Próximo paso** – Las autoridades tailandesas deben asegurar que el proceso de solicitud sea claro, justo y rápido, protegiendo a los refugiados de abusos. Si se implementa bien, esta medida puede aumentar la independencia de los refugiados y estimular las economías locales, sirviendo como modelo para otros países de la región.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Los nuevos permisos de trabajo en Tailandia dan a los refugiados birmanos la oportunidad de vivir con más independencia y contribuir a sus comunidades por primera vez en décadas.

articles.title: Brazil One Step Away from Protecting Children Online
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              The Brazilian Senate in Brasilia, February 1, 2021.
                    © 2021 Sergio Lima/AFP via Getty Images
          
    


  
Today, Brazil’s Senate passed a long-awaited bill to protect children’s rights online. The bill now heads for President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva’s signature into law.If enacted, this legislation would impose sweeping digital safety and privacy safeguards for children. It would compel tech companies to design products with young users’ best interests in mind and provide children with the highest levels of privacy by default.Two of the bill’s strongest provisions respond to concerns directly raised in recent Human Rights Watch investigations. One provision prohibits online services from using children’s personal data in ways that “cause, facilitate, or contribute to the violation of their privacy or any other rights guaranteed to them by law … and the[ir] best interests.” In June 2024, we documented how children’s personal photos had been used to build powerful artificial intelligence tools later exploited to create abusive deepfakes of other children.Another safeguard in the bill bans profiling children – tracking children’s online behavior to predict their characteristics, behaviors, and interests – to target them with behavioral advertising. This reflects recommendations in April 2023 and May 2022 Human Rights Watch investigations, which documented that children in Brazil and around the world had been secretly surveilled in their online classrooms and across the internet through invasive profiling and behavioral advertising techniques.Passage of this bill reflects strong political will to protect children online. Before being approved by the Senate today, the bill had unanimously passed the Senate in December 2024 and cleared the Chamber of Deputies last week with support from all but one political party, Novo.This broad support enabled the bill’s passage despite fierce opposition from tech companies, which successfully weakened some of the legislation’s original proposals. These include banning “loot boxes” in video games – features that encourage children to spend money for randomized rewards – and requiring companies to exercise a duty of care towards children. It is also unclear how one provision – mandating that children’s social media accounts be linked to their guardians’ accounts – might be implemented in a way that preserves children’s privacy and their right to seek information.President Lula should sign the bill without delay and provide Brazilian children the protections they need to learn, explore, and play safely online.
articles.content:
Click to expand Image The Brazilian Senate in Brasilia, February 1, 2021. © 2021 Sergio Lima/AFP via Getty Images

Today, Brazil’s Senate passed a long-awaited bill to protect children’s rights online. The bill now heads for President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva’s signature into law.

If enacted, this legislation would impose sweeping digital safety and privacy safeguards for children. It would compel tech companies to design products with young users’ best interests in mind and provide children with the highest levels of privacy by default.

Two of the bill’s strongest provisions respond to concerns directly raised in recent Human Rights Watch investigations. One provision prohibits online services from using children’s personal data in ways that “cause, facilitate, or contribute to the violation of their privacy or any other rights guaranteed to them by law … and the[ir] best interests.” In June 2024, we documented how children’s personal photos had been used to build powerful artificial intelligence tools later exploited to create abusive deepfakes of other children.

Another safeguard in the bill bans profiling children – tracking children’s online behavior to predict their characteristics, behaviors, and interests – to target them with behavioral advertising. This reflects recommendations in April 2023 and May 2022 Human Rights Watch investigations, which documented that children in Brazil and around the world had been secretly surveilled in their online classrooms and across the internet through invasive profiling and behavioral advertising techniques.

Passage of this bill reflects strong political will to protect children online. Before being approved by the Senate today, the bill had unanimously passed the Senate in December 2024 and cleared the Chamber of Deputies last week with support from all but one political party, Novo.

This broad support enabled the bill’s passage despite fierce opposition from tech companies, which successfully weakened some of the legislation’s original proposals. These include banning “loot boxes” in video games – features that encourage children to spend money for randomized rewards – and requiring companies to exercise a duty of care towards children. It is also unclear how one provision – mandating that children’s social media accounts be linked to their guardians’ accounts – might be implemented in a way that preserves children’s privacy and their right to seek information.

President Lula should sign the bill without delay and provide Brazilian children the protections they need to learn, explore, and play safely online.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on Brazil's Senate passing a significant bill to protect children's digital rights and privacy, which has broad societal impact. The legislation mandates tech companies to safeguard children's data and prevent harmful profiling and advertising practices, addressing real-world issues documented by Human Rights Watch. The bill has strong political support and, once signed into law, will provide meaningful protections for children online.
articles.personality_title: Brazil’s Senate approves major bill to protect children’s online privacy
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In recent years, concerns have grown about how children’s personal information is used online. Investigations found that children’s photos were misused and their online activities tracked to show them targeted ads. Brazil has been working on laws to better protect children in the digital world.

**What happened** – On February 1, 2025, Brazil’s Senate passed a new bill aimed at protecting children’s rights on the internet. The bill will now go to President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva for approval. If signed, it will require tech companies to design their products with children’s safety and privacy as a top priority. It also bans using children’s data in harmful ways and stops companies from tracking children’s online behavior to target them with ads.

**Impact** – This law is important because it directly addresses problems found by Human Rights Watch, such as children’s photos being used to create harmful fake videos and children being secretly watched online. The bill has strong political support and shows Brazil’s commitment to keeping children safe while they learn and play online. Some parts of the original bill were weakened after tech companies pushed back, but the core protections remain.

**What's next step** – The bill now waits for President Lula’s signature. Once signed, it will become law, and tech companies will need to follow the new rules. This may lead to safer online spaces for children in Brazil and could inspire other countries to adopt similar protections.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Brazil’s new law will protect children’s privacy online by limiting how tech companies use their data and preventing harmful tracking and advertising.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Sénat brésilien adopte une loi majeure pour protéger la vie privée des enfants en ligne
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Ces dernières années, des inquiétudes ont grandi sur l’utilisation des informations personnelles des enfants sur Internet. Des enquêtes ont révélé que des photos d’enfants étaient mal utilisées et que leurs activités en ligne étaient surveillées pour leur montrer des publicités ciblées. Le Brésil travaille à des lois pour mieux protéger les enfants dans le monde numérique.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 1er février 2025, le Sénat brésilien a adopté un nouveau projet de loi visant à protéger les droits des enfants sur Internet. Le texte doit maintenant être signé par le président Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. S’il est approuvé, il obligera les entreprises technologiques à concevoir leurs produits en plaçant la sécurité et la vie privée des enfants au premier plan. Il interdit aussi l’utilisation abusive des données des enfants et empêche le suivi de leur comportement en ligne pour leur envoyer des publicités.

**Impact** – Cette loi est importante car elle répond directement aux problèmes relevés par Human Rights Watch, comme l’utilisation abusive des photos d’enfants pour créer de fausses vidéos nuisibles et la surveillance secrète des enfants en ligne. Le projet a un large soutien politique et montre l’engagement du Brésil pour protéger les enfants pendant qu’ils apprennent et jouent en ligne. Certaines parties ont été affaiblies après la pression des entreprises technologiques, mais les principales protections restent en place.

**Prochaine étape** – Le projet attend maintenant la signature du président Lula. Une fois signé, il deviendra loi et les entreprises devront respecter ces nouvelles règles. Cela pourrait rendre les espaces en ligne plus sûrs pour les enfants au Brésil et inspirer d’autres pays à adopter des protections similaires.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La nouvelle loi brésilienne protégera la vie privée des enfants en limitant l’utilisation de leurs données par les entreprises technologiques et en empêchant le suivi et la publicité nuisibles.
articles.personality_title_es: El Senado de Brasil aprueba una ley importante para proteger la privacidad de los niños en línea
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En los últimos años, han aumentado las preocupaciones sobre cómo se usan los datos personales de los niños en internet. Investigaciones mostraron que se usaban fotos de niños de manera incorrecta y que sus actividades en línea eran vigiladas para mostrarles anuncios dirigidos. Brasil ha estado trabajando en leyes para proteger mejor a los niños en el mundo digital.

**Qué pasó** – El 1 de febrero de 2025, el Senado de Brasil aprobó un nuevo proyecto de ley para proteger los derechos de los niños en internet. Ahora el proyecto espera la firma del presidente Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. Si se aprueba, exigirá que las empresas tecnológicas diseñen sus productos pensando en la seguridad y privacidad de los niños. También prohíbe el uso dañino de los datos de los niños y detiene el seguimiento de su comportamiento en línea para dirigirles anuncios.

**Impacto** – Esta ley es importante porque responde directamente a problemas identificados por Human Rights Watch, como el uso indebido de fotos de niños para crear videos falsos dañinos y la vigilancia secreta de los niños en línea. El proyecto cuenta con un fuerte apoyo político y muestra el compromiso de Brasil para proteger a los niños mientras aprenden y juegan en línea. Algunas partes del proyecto original fueron debilitadas tras la presión de las empresas tecnológicas, pero las protecciones principales permanecen.

**Próximo paso** – El proyecto ahora espera la firma del presidente Lula. Una vez firmado, se convertirá en ley y las empresas deberán seguir las nuevas reglas. Esto puede crear espacios en línea más seguros para los niños en Brasil e inspirar a otros países a adoptar protecciones similares.

**Resumen en una frase** – La nueva ley de Brasil protegerá la privacidad de los niños en línea limitando el uso de sus datos y evitando el seguimiento y la publicidad dañina.

articles.title: Iraq unveils historic migration plan to boost development and stability
articles.summary: Iraq has taken an historic step with the launch of its first ever national migration plan, designed to promote safe, orderly and regular pathways for Iraqis returning home and around 370,000 migrants living and working inside the country.
articles.content:
Unveiled on Wednesday, it creates new opportunities for work, education and family reunification, while strengthening migration governance and placing migration at the heart of stability and economic development.

It is being led by Iraq’s ministry for migration and the displaced, with the support of the International Organization for Migration (IOM) and the Government of the Netherlands - translating Iraq’s global commitments into national action.

Migration minister Evan Faeq Gabro said that it represents a “vision for Iraq’s future that upholds human dignity”, serves national interests, and supports the Global Compact for Migration.

“Iraq is setting an example for the region and beyond, showing how national leadership and genuine partnership can turn migration into an engine for dignity, opportunity, and development,” said Ugochi Daniels, IOM’s Deputy Director General for Operations.

Origin and destination

Iraq is both a country of origin and destination, with some two million nationals currently living abroad, while thousands more are weighing emigration.

In the past seven years, over 58,000 people have returned to Iraq, rebuilding their lives at home.

Meanwhile, the country also hosts some 370,000 migrant workers, mainly engaged in semi-skilled sectors such as construction and domestic work.

Iraq’s five-year National Plan to Promote Safe, Orderly and Regular Migration emphasises data-driven decision-making, stronger institutional coordination and calls for closer private sector involvement.

Stability and development

“This national plan demonstrates that when policies are grounded in evidence and shaped by people’s needs, migration can benefit migrants, communities, and the country as a whole,” said Ms Daniels.

Th new policy responds to Iraq’s current migration realities, framing migration as a tool for national development and stability, says IOM.

“Today, we are here to commit ourselves to ensuring that migration is about dignity, safety, and opportunity for migrants, their families, and the communities they join,” said Claudio Cordone, UN Deputy Special Representative in Iraq.

The plan outlines a vision for a future that upholds human dignity and serves the national interest.

articles.personality_title_es: Irak lanza su primer plan nacional de migración para mejorar seguridad y desarrollo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Irak tiene muchos ciudadanos viviendo en el extranjero y alrededor de 370,000 migrantes trabajando en el país. Durante años, el país ha enfrentado desafíos relacionados con la migración y la necesidad de apoyar a quienes regresan o viven como migrantes.

**Qué pasó** – El miércoles, Irak presentó su primer plan nacional de migración. Este plan busca crear caminos seguros y ordenados para que los iraquíes que regresan y los migrantes encuentren trabajo, educación y puedan reunirse con sus familias. El plan está dirigido por el Ministerio de Migración y Desplazados de Irak, con el apoyo de la Organización Internacional para las Migraciones (OIM) y el gobierno de los Países Bajos.

**Impacto** – Este plan es importante porque pone la migración en el centro del desarrollo y la estabilidad de Irak. Se enfoca en tomar decisiones basadas en datos reales, mejorar la cooperación entre instituciones y aumentar la participación del sector privado. También respeta la dignidad humana al asegurar mejores y más seguras oportunidades para los migrantes y sus familias.

**Próximo paso** – Irak trabajará ahora para implementar este plan de cinco años. Esto implica mejorar la gestión de la migración, ayudar a los migrantes y retornados a establecerse bien, y fomentar un papel más activo de las empresas. El plan podría servir como modelo para otros países con desafíos similares.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El nuevo plan nacional de migración de Irak busca convertir la migración en una fuerza positiva para la seguridad, las oportunidades y el crecimiento económico.
